author: potuz
content: Your validator is assigned to vote in slot `N` to attest what's its view of the head of the chain. When that slot arrives, normally he receives a block, processes it and then attests for the hash of that block as its new head

author: potuz
content: If the block does not arrive in time though, then your validator will assume there is no block, and attest for the previous head at slot `N-1`

author: bitmexresearch
content: Oh I get it, it votes assuming that slot is missed

author: potuz
content: That's his view of the world at the time he is supposed to attest

author: bitmexresearch
content: Another question, producer block rewards are multiplied by the number of attestations inside the block to incentivise inclusion of the votes. Is that correct?

author: potuz
content: They are not multiplied, each attestation that is included ads some rewards to the block producer (this reward may vary from attestation to attestation).. But yes, you need to incentivize inclusion of attestations otherwise block producers would produce empty blocks and broadcsst earlier

author: potuz
content: I myself think that it may be better to reward blocks by the number of votes they get, or by a combination of the two. But it's not clear if doing so opens a door to censorship

author: pietjepuk
content:
> As a general rule of thumb, the proposer of a block gets 1/8 of the rewards given to other validators in the block that they include. This ensures sufficient incentive to include attestations and other objects as well as incentive to produce blocks.

You can check the specs https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/phase0/beacon-chain.md#process_rewards_and_penalties or an annotated version ( https://github.com/ethereum/annotated-spec/blob/master/phase0/beacon-chain.md ).
Do note that Altair will change things a bit, you can check the details in those respective repositories

author: jgm
content: Note that the 1/8 number is incorrect for the current mainnet, it's in fact approximately 1/32.  It is meant to be 1/8, though, and Altair addresses this.
